article.title: The QCD mass gap and quark deconfinement scales as mass bounds in strong gravity

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows a table of contents. Which section discusses the Buchdahl inequality?
choices: A. Section I: Introduction
B. Section II: Tolman-Oppenheimer-Volkoff Equation in the Strong Gravity Model
C. Section III: The Buchdahl inequality and the minimum and maximum mass/radius ratios of stable compact objects in strong gravity
D. Section IV: The mass gap in strong gravity

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula represents the Buchdahl inequality for strongly interacting particles. What does the constant 8/9 represent?
choices: A. The maximum allowable mass of a black hole in strong gravity.
B. The critical density required for quark deconfinement.
C. The upper limit on the mass-to-radius ratio for stable hadrons in strong gravity.
D. The strength of the coupling between the strong and weak gravitational fields.

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula expresses the minimum mass/radius ratio of hadronic particles in strong gravity. What does the term M^2 represent?
choices: A. The square of the Planck mass in strong gravity.
B. The square of the strong cosmological constant.
C. The square of the mass parameter controlling the mixing between the strong and weak gravitational fields.
D. The square of the Hagedorn temperature.

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula presents the quantum minimum mass bound for neutral particles in strong gravity. What are msP and msd?
choices: A. The masses of the proton and neutron, respectively.
B. The masses of the up and down quarks, respectively.
C. The Planck mass and de Sitter mass scales in strong gravity, respectively.
D. The Salam mass scales in strong gravity.

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula estimates the minimum mass of a stable, strongly interacting, quantum mechanical particle with charge Q in strong gravity. What does Î±Q represent?
choices: A. The fine structure constant scaled by the ratio of the particle\'s charge to the Planck charge squared.
B. The strong coupling constant scaled by the particle\'s charge.
C. The strength of the mixing between the strong and weak gravitational fields for a charged particle.
D. The inverse of the strong gravity Compton wavelength.
